title: Can I get Penalized for Telling Someone that I Reported/Muted them?
body: Rather than starting an argument with a toxic player, I prefer to just tell them that I reported/muted them and move on with the game. Though I am just making sure, is this considered toxic behavior and will I get penalized for saying this? Or am I safe?

replies.body:
Asking for reports, using reports as a weapon or leverage, and telling someone you're going to report them can be considered player harassment.

 Realistically speaking I don't think you'll receive a punishment for that alone, but it could compound with other parts of your chat to warrant a punishment. It's better to just mute the person and report them at the end of the match, there's no need to tell them what you plan on doing.

I have an easy temper, and care too much about what a toxic enemy thinks of me. I don't want to mute all/team chat and be bored with no chat, so this is my best option to avoid arguing.

Probably not, to be honest. Riot hasn't explicitly said anything about that but I just don't think it's on the same level. 

 Even then, I would still just mute the person and move on. It's probably not going to make their experience any better and if they know you've muted them there's a slim chance they might move on to other areas of negativity like griefing or AFKing.

But what if that person you muted doesn't know you muted them, and is trying any form of communication, let's say a jungler, trying to gank the lane you're on, but they don't know you muted them so the gank turns out backfiring due to lack of communication other than knowing your jungler is around because you see it on map. I've seen players get tilted because other players "ignored" them when they were actually chat/ping muted and led to missplays.

If you're not bming or further pushing a player to get tilted, I pesonally don't find any issue in letting people know they're being muted as long as it's just that, without any other message, so both players can move on. If the muted player moves on to griefing or afking, that behavior would happen even if that player wasn't told to be muted, because that mentality would be triggered by anything that goes wrong in the match anyway.

If you just say, "muted," then the answer is no. 

if you say, "alright i muted this dumbass that's so much better," then maybe

The automated punishment system _seems to be_ based on keywords, frequency of chat, frequency of keywords, and reports
